posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Conan the Barbarian, on every level. It's probably the only movie I can think of where the framework is similar to Thus Spoke Zarathustra.
>Hero returns to civilization with wisdom gained from being outside it, being willing to live outside what is "good" and learns from it
>Hero rejects ideology, responds emotionally and physically to philosophy
>Hero is frequently self-serving and contradictory, only loyal to himself and what he values, not any rigid morality
>Defies and destroys a society that opposes him by overcoming trials and becoming strong enough that he cannot be opposed anymore
>Embraces his power and a life of conflict rather than seeking solace from pain
The two things it lacks is a sequel in which he does the same to the society created around him because it has fallen from his grace, naturally, and a sequence where Conan embraces what he perceives as a weakness to make it a strength.
The Riddick series has aspects of this as well, but through a more modern, progressive lens.

>>178920470
This whole scene, in fact, is a reference to Nietzschean philosophy. Hotheads would never understand.

First, when Agent Wilson calls Bane a "big guy" he's clearly referencing him as the Übermensch, while himself indulges in slave morality represented by the authoritarian institution that is Central Intelligence Agency. Note how Wilson never references himself as his real name. There is no individuality in him, only CIA. The essence of slave morality (represented as the "flight plan", opposed to master morality - the "master plan") is utility: the good is what is most useful for the whole community, not the strong. But he does not see beyond palpable good and evil.

Also prior to the scene, Wilson shoots out of the plane without actually killing anyone. He does so out of misguided anger, furious that neither faith in god nor scientific knowledge has not given him the rest or respite he desires. At the same time, CIA shooting the sky symbolizes the death of God as a source of morality for people, leading to the unhooding of Bane, the Übermensch.

When Bane crashes the plane with no survivors, he's crashing the entire worldview based on slave morality. He's crashing old thoughts and institutions such as religions. He's crashing secular humanism. He's crashing herd mentality. He's crashing even himself, as he overcomes his former self to become the over-man. In this crash, a fire rises in the wreckage - the triumph of "life" over "logic"

Then, in the end Bane reminds Dr. Pavel that "Now is not the time for fear, that comes later!" The world is necessarily moved in a cycle, endlessly repeating all past events due to finite amount of matter and infinite amount of time. In this eternal recurrence, the plane crash will repeat - again and again.

But if life triumphs over logic, the only meaning is life then is the will to power, that means the big guy will always be in charge here.

Bravo Nolan.

The reason there are multiple interpretations is because Nietzsche fundamentally deals with subjective truths about ourselves from the perspective of an artist, thus there is no true or false or any other binary categories we can put his philosophy into. It must be felt and understood intuitively.

I always recommend starting with Birth of Tragedy for the reason that it facilitates a more artistic interpretation of the world and I personally believe that most of Nietzsche's later philosophy is mostly polish and corollary to it.

Also, very few people read BT for some reason, which is probably why common ground cannot be found.

>>178928565
Nihilism is the exact opposite of a "lay down and die" ideology because it's entirely rooted in personal responsibility. You have no destiny, so you must create the path yourself. There is no absolute morality, so you must use your reason, wit and criticality to determine what you view to be right and wrong, and you must act in accordance with those principles at all times, even though there is no promise of divine reward for doing so. A real man requires no eternal heavenly recompense for doing the right thing, they simply do it because they believe it is right. Nothing else could ever be honest. Enlightenment is its own reward. If you need a belief system to orient your life for you, it is because you are weak and your brain is a flabby atrophied muscle that hurts to exercise. Same if you need a sense of community because you have no individuality or drive, or if you need a deity for much of the same reasons. You can't navigate life as an adult without a parental figure telling you everything you need to know, so you invent the ultimate parental figure in God, an entity that always knows better than you and can't make mistakes because he isn't beholden to human fallibility. This also means he's static. He can't grow or learn, or adapt, and so neither can you.

>>178928814
>I see people constantly wank frames per second like it's some kind of fucking sin to go below a certain number and nobody can explain it.
It is. Animation is the illusion of movement, you drop the frame rate to the laughably low levels we're now seeing and the illusion is broken and you become very aware that you're just looking at a series of pictures instead of something actually happening. It breaks immersion, which is why people hate it. You either have a high tolerance for how low the framerate can get before it breaks your immersion or you just simply don't care about the things you watch like some kind of braindead npc (it's probably the latter).

I had this conversation with my much younger cousin who attends a rich (read lefty) private school near London.
The name: Cho Chang, which is a mix of common and uncommon westernised Chinese names, is considered offensive because it sounds, particularly to young people who haven't been exposed to much of the outside world, even to asians who have never been to Asia, like a racist stereotype word vomit - like Ching Chong if you will. With the zeitgeist being what it is, and the popularity of the series, you're always going to get misguided youth seeking to be politically virtuous making misinformed accusations of racism against Rowling for this,even if it's a tad ironic. Not all opinions are valid.
The second argument for Rowling's racism tends to be lack of representation in the HP books. This more betrays the fact that lefties cannot into intersectionality, growing up themselves in city or private schools which will have a largely diverse student body. Back in Rowlings day schools were much more white and most of my (British) parents, grandparents and appropriately aged relatives had no minority classmates. Minorities are technically overrepresnted in her books given her likely experience in school (depending on where she went to school).
It's a more difficult conversation to sway someone on but also representation wasn't a moral imperative at the time the books were written.

andor is legitimately good. like not just "good for star wars" but actually good. even if you know nothing about star wars or its characters you can enjoy it, its a serious and well told story that treats its characters with respect and has a good degree of tension, high stakes, and consequences, and the ending is poetic and inspiring

kenobi looks like it was filmed in a construction site by a bunch of fucking highschoolers on a phone camera when they just happened to find ewan mcgregor attending a comic con or something, its tragically low effort, terribly written, and although i think mcgregor is a decent actor he was given absolutely nothing to work with. the majority of the run time focuses on a 10 year old leia doing her best home alone impression and some new inquisitor lady who is overacting to a severe degree, although how much of that is her and how much of that is just the poor direction is difficult to discern.

boba fett was....directionless. they had a somewhat interesting hook with his character in the mandolorian series of redemption and renewed honor, but then when it came time to make his spinoff show they lost the plot, and it just felt like aimless wandering for 6 episodes. there were some good characters and scenes, and while it wasnt great it was nowhere near as bad as kenobi, and not quite as bad as people on here make it out to be although it was a bit boring. a missed opportunity but not the tragedy that kenobi was.

If we are talking about /tv/ then it is universally agreed that Kenobi and BOBF are bad - and even outside of /tv/ then many people pretty quickly turned against them. Perhaps the most baffling thing of about BOBF is it comes across as DLC for Mando (with the show eventually becoming Mando S2.5); and the most baffling thing about Kenobi is it is the one show that should have actually taken place on Tatooine. Far less people have watched Andor (many people don't seem to be able to get past the first few episodes) and opinion seems to be mixed. Personally, I liked Andor (well-written, well-acted, well-produced, the Empire is not a joke), although I can see why people either won't give it a go or are not able to get into it. Common opposition to Andor seems to be 'too slow / passing issues', 'lesbians' and 'it's Disney'. One thing to add about Andor is it is really more of an ensemble than being just about Andor: there is also clear focus/stories upon Luthen, Mon Mothma, Syril and Dedra that have various levels of interwovenness.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>178929438
Why?

Did you even understand my point? Sure, there are about 1000 films in the world that are better than Reservoir Dogs. At least 500 films that are better than Pulp Fiction. But the people who made those films didn't just wake up one day and go "alright, I'll write Reservoir Dogs and the next summer I'll direct it even though I have zero professional film experience" and then attain immediate success.

Let's compare Tarantino to another modern American auteur, Paul Thomas Anderson:

>father was an actor who was working in Hollywood and encouraged him to become a writer or a director
>made his first film when he was eight
>father bought him a video camera when he was 12
>made a shit load of short films, each bigger and more complex than the last
>finally as a high school senior he used his savings to make a 30 minute mockumentary film called The Dirk Diggler Story (which he would later turn into Boogie Nights)
>went to Santa Monica College to study film
>went to Emerson College to study writing (one of his teachers was David Foster Wallace)
>went to NYU film school for 2 days before dropping out to become a production assistant on film, TV, music videos and game shows
>used his savings, his girlfriend's credit card and the money his father had put aside for his college fees to make a professional quality 25 minute short film
>the short film got into Sundance and that allowed him to participate in Sundance's directors' lab where he got mentored by experienced and acclaimed professionals like the director of Midnight Cowboy

His filmmaking capabilities were learned through the years by practicing, practicing and practicing. Tarantino just wrote a feature film, directed it and pretty much instantly shot up higher than Anderson has ever gotten.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>178930324
Yeah, 50k for a script was peanuts back in the day. Probably the lowest amount they could legally pay for a script because they were a WGA signatory company.

Here's some script sales from 1991:

https://gointothestory.blcklst.com/the-definitive-spec-script-sales-list-1991-2012-1991-d54ad864729d

Title: Ocean Boulevard
>Actress takes on the mental and physical qualities of an imprisoned woman whose life she’s studying for a role.
Price: $1.5M

Title: Mrs. Faust
>Small town divorcee is given a 30 day free trial by the devil to have all her wishes granted.
Price: $500K/$700K

Title: Sessions
>Female detective investigating sex related murder in NYC becomes involved with a sexy therapist, who is the prime suspect in the case.
Price: Over $1M

Title: Cutthroat Island
>Pirate bounty hunter who can’t shoot, sail, or swim teams up with a feisty woman, who helps him battle a band of cutthroats in search of a hidden treasure.
Price: $500K

Title: Nature of the Beast
>Guy can’t keep his zipper zipped and is forced to learn sexual restraint.
Price: $250K

Title: Geek
>Fable about a man who thinks he’s a rooster. He’s sent to a mental institution where young female doctor helps him return to a normal lifestyle.
Price: $1.5M

Title: Boys of Summer
>Set in summer, 1962, story is about nine 11 year-old boys, one of them, an outsider trying to fit in.
Price: $1M

Now do the math on how much those sums would be in today's dollars.

>>178924859
>So why did none of this shit exist by the time the settlers arrived?
As the various other Anons have mentioned, there are records from early Spanish Explorers of the large civilizations with settled towns such as the Mississippi Mound Builders.
When the later English explorers went thru those same areas a century or so later, these large cities or settlements were mostly empty or abandoned.
The general theory, is that the Spanish explorers, and maybe early French explorers brought diseases, that somehow spread thru many of the various Native ethnic groups and wiped those groups out, and caused the survivors to flee and become migratory groups.
There is dpecilation that North America may have been way more organized for trade amongst the various native populations than was previously proposed, with some groups raising Buffalo in the central grass kands, and then trading those buffalo, or products from those buffalo to groups on either coast, with other long range trade going on as well, such as trade in large natural copper ingots across Canada and the North.
This could explain how disease could spread so quickly and wipe out huge numbers of natives, possibly in the millions.
Later settlers thought the early accounts from Spain were bullshit, since there were a lot of weird stories from early explorers.

There’s another theory, that when the Roman Empire came to sack Carthage in North Africa, that many of the Carthaginians fled in the ships they were known for, and came to the Americas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178930810
It's for verisimilitude, which is actually something that comes from the novels, as well as the more cynical and overriding reason of money.
Fleming started writing in the 1950s, when Britain was still badly suffering the effects of wartime rationing. The vast majority of people were unable to buy any sort of luxury goods, even the more well-off classes, and so Fleming tapped into this by making Bond this cultured man of expensive tastes. Every time a car or gun or dress or drink comes up in the books, he describes exactly what it is and what expensive or famous brand it happens to be. Bond doesn't just drive a nice car, he drives a 1931 4.5 Litre Blower Bentley. The borderline-obsessive attention to detail places Bond in the real world, albeit a world that none of his readers could ever know themselves, and the realism also helps to paper over the more fantastical and stupid bits of the plot. Then with the films that need for Bond to be seen using real-life luxury brands translated to lucrative product placement deals and endorsements, to the joy of MGM producers and ad executives everywhere.

Edwyn Frey shoved her aside. The music drowned all other sound, echoing off the walls as if the stones themselves were playing. Robb gave Edwyn an angry look and moved to block his way . . . and staggered suddenly as a quarrel sprouted from his side, just beneath the shoulder. If he screamed then, the sound was swallowed by the pipes and horns and fiddles. Catelyn saw a second bolt pierce his leg, saw him fall. Up in the gallery, half the musicians had crossbows in their hands instead of drums or lutes. She ran toward her son, until something punched in the small of the back and the hard stone floor came up to slap her. “Robb!” she screamed. She saw Smalljon Umber wrestle a table off its trestles. Crossbow bolts thudded into the wood, one two three, as he flung it down on top of his king. Robin Flint was ringed by Freys, their daggers rising and falling. Ser Wendel Manderly rose ponderously to his feet, holding his leg of lamb. A quarrel went in his open mouth and came out the back of his neck. Ser Wendel crashed forward, knocking the table off its trestles and sending cups, flagons, trenchers, platters, turnips, beets, and wine bouncing, spilling, and sliding across the floor.
Catelyn’s back was on fire. I have to reach him. The Smalljon bludgeoned Ser Raymund Frey across the face with a leg of mutton. But when he reached for his swordbelt a crossbow bolt drove him to his knees. In a coat of gold or a coat of red, a lion still has claws. She saw Lucas Blackwood cut down by Ser Hosteen Frey. One of the Vances was hamstrung by Black Walder as he was wrestling with Ser Harys Haigh. And mine are long and sharp, my lord, as long and sharp as yours. The crossbows took Donnel Locke, Owen Norrey, and half a dozen more. Young Ser Benfrey had seized Dacey Mormont by the arm, but Catelyn saw her grab up a flagon of wine with her other hand, smash it full in his face, and run for the door. It flew open before she reached it.

Ser Ryman Frey pushed into the hall, clad in steel from helm to heel. A dozen Frey men-at-arms packed the door behind him. They were armed with heavy longaxes.
“Mercy!” Catelyn cried, but horns and drums and the clash of steel smothered her plea. Ser Ryman buried the head of his axe in Dacey’s stomach. By then men were pouring in the other doors as well, mailed men in shaggy fur cloaks with steel in their hands. Northmen! She took them for rescue for half a heartbeat, till one of them struck the Smalljon’s head off with two huge blows of his axe. Hope blew out like a candle in a storm.
In the midst of slaughter, the Lord of the Crossing sat on his carved oaken throne, watching greedily.
There was a dagger on the floor a few feet away. Perhaps it had skittered there when the Smalljon knocked the table off its trestles, or perhaps it had fallen from the hand of some dying man. Catelyn crawled toward it. Her limbs were leaden, and the taste of blood was in her mouth. I will kill Walder Frey, she told herself. Jinglebell was closer to the knife, hiding under a table, but he only cringed away as she snatched up the blade. I will kill the old man, I can do that much at least.
Then the tabletop that the Smalljon had flung over Robb shifted, and her son struggled to his knees. He had an arrow in his side, a second in his leg, a third through his chest. Lord Walder raised a hand, and the music stopped, all but one drum. Catelyn heard the crash of distant battle, and closer the wild howling of a wolf. Grey Wind, she remembered too late. “Heh,” Lord Walder cackled at Robb, “the King in the North arises. Seems we killed some of your men, Your Grace. Oh, but I’ll make you an apology, that will mend them all again, heh.”
Catelyn grabbed a handful of Jinglebell Frey’s long grey hair and dragged him out of his hiding place. “Lord Walder!” she shouted. “LORD WALDER!” The drum beat slow and sonorous, doom boom doom. “Enough,” said Catelyn.

>>178919077
It’s his acting tick. All actors have one but they usually learn to manage it over time. He parts his lips when he’s being shot reacting to stuff because it feels weird to be filmed just standing there doing nothing. You feel like you have do to something. Inexperienced actors have a hard time just being normal or passive. Sanford Meisner used to say you could be the smartest guy in the world, you could read every book on the subject of acting and understand theory perfectly well, but then as you get up on stage you forget how to sit in a chair. Usually this manifests as not knowing what to do with your hands. People also have the tendency to slap their thighs to emphasize a point at the end of a sentence. Sometimes people will gesticulate weirdly, sometimes they fall into one repetitive inflections and say every line the same way. Emilia Clarke acts with her eyebrows. Happens to everybody when they’re just starting out

The Iron Bank is definitely inspired by those strong ass Italian banks in the Middle Ages, so yes, definitely. The Bank knows entire noble families/kingdoms depend on it, so as long as it doesn't overtly hold another type of power (military/religious), not like it needs to anyway, it's going to play the game for a long time.
There ARE constant wars among the Free Cities too, but I think the very fact that their ruling class comes from ancient Ghiscari/Valyrian families puts them above anything in Westeros, especially when it comes to wealth. People like Varys, Ilyrio or Mellisandre seem to be individual agents though and big exceptions. The only actual organisation I see actively spreading its influence in Westeros is the R'hllor cult. Otherwise we don't have noble, say, Lyseni families infiltrating Westeros right now, but former slaves/poor people who rose to positions of relative power on their own.
